Ongoing commitment to ensure that all road users are safe.  Police were out early this morning conducting roadside breath testing on Princes Hwy Hoppers Crossing when a 28yo Wyndham Vale male was requested undergo a breath test. Police allege that the male, a learner driver with no accompanying driver, returned a positive reading. He was then required to undergo a test at Werribee Police Station and returned an alleged reading of 0.101 Learner drivers must be 0.00 and have a full licensed driver seated beside them. The male had his learner permit suspended and will attend court at a later date.

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Shepparton Police Service Area
Post Message: NOT JUST ONE BUS, WAIT THERE'S MORE.....  Seymour was not the place to be on Friday night for anyone who may have been thinking they could get away with driving whilst either drug or alchol affected.  Not only was a booze bus in town, but a drug bus was out and about as well.  Results are in from the booze bus, which saw two drivers having their vehicles impounded after being detected well and truly over the legal limit.  A 42-year-old Mordialloc man blew .113% and a man from Avenel, aged in his late 20's gave a breath test result of .124%.  They have both said goodbye to their cars for a month and will be facing court.    Another driver, a man in his 50's, again from Avenel was given a penalty notice for his breath test reading of .09% and one other was caught for not displaying "P" Plates.  We are still awaiting results from the drug bus.

SOMETIMES THERE IS A POLICEMAN ABOUT WHEN YOU WANT ONE  Somerville HWP had a busy time Saturday evening about 7pm after being called to a minor collision on Frankston-Dandenong Rd under Peninsula Link at Carrum Downs. Whilst attending to the collision, a young male driving a V8 Commodore ute came off the Peninsula Link exit sideways onto Frankston-Dandenong Rd whilst spinning his wheels. He was intercepted, went positive on a drug test and his ute was impounded. Whilst waiting for that tow to arrive another V8 Commodore, this one driven by a 'P' plater, exited the other Peninsula Link Off-Ramp whilst also revving his motor, spinning his wheels and coming sideways onto Frankston-Dandenong Rd towards police. He was also intercepted and his car impounded. Both male drivers will be summonsed to appear at the Frankston Magistrates' Court at a later date.    (Author: VP30339)

PENINSULA LINK TOW-TRUCK COLLISION UPDATE  Somerville HWP Police today charged a 39 y.o. Frankston North man with negligently causing serious injury and other offences in relation to the collision between a car  and tow truck on Peninsula Link last Tuesday 14-Nov-2017. The man has been bailed to appear at the Melbourne Magistrates' Court on Friday the 24th of November 2017.  The victim remains in a stable condition in the Alfred Hospital, and police would like to thank all those persons who stopped to assist at the scene or have provided information.  (Author: VP30339)

Acting Senior Sergeant Brendan Summers met with staff from Rowville Centrelink/Medicare office last week to discuss various community issues occurring within the Rowville response zone. The impacts that drugs, crime & family violence has on clients & their families, and more generally in the community, were discussed as well as the support services both organisations can offer to assist those in need.   This local partnership at Rowville sees Victoria Police and Centrelink/Medicare working together to share intelligence & establish a good working relationship, offering support and collaboration with each other for the benefit of the community.   Centrelink/Medicare staff will be accompanying police to the next Coffee with a Cop - occurring at Gloria Jeans, Stud Park, Stud Road, Rowville, on Tuesday the 5th of December. We hope to see you there!

ASSAULT DURING TOAST THE COAST  On 04-NOV-2017 complainant was at Terindah Estate, Bellarine (Winery) attending a Toast the Coast event.  At approximately  2.45 pm the female victim received a phone call so she walked away from event to escape the noise about 200 metres into vineyard.  Victim was followed by an unknown male who approached her and began asking her questions whilst she was on the phone. Male then kissed her on lips without warning or permission. Complainant pushed him away and said 'No, stop.'  The male has then picked up a pine cone or rock and struck the complainant on the forehead with it before running off back towards the main event area. Male was not sighted again by the victim.  Male described, Caucasian, late 20's - early 30's, brown hair, clean shaven, thin build, white shirt, black slacks.  Any information to Detective Senior Constable Glenn BENSTED ‚Äì Geelong SOCIT on 52468100 or Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Dandenong Police Service Area
Post Message: A story about policing that members of the community don‚Äôt often get to see but still an important one!   vp40485

Afternoon shift log: Tuesday 21st November 2017 Callsign: Wyndham North 303 Patrol Crew: Senior Constable Frank & Probationary Constable Daniel.  Covering the city of Wyndham: 225,000 people, 541 sq km.  1430: Arrive at work, grab equipment, checked equipment, prepare shift, reading latest intel, emails, chasing up a few loose ends from previous shifts.  1450: Safety & shift briefing, including vehicle inspection.  1510: Logged onto the Mobile Data Terminal.  No outstanding jobs, which is odd.   On patrol, carrying out some patrol tasking of Presidents Park, Galvin Park area, Market Rd area.  1548:  Vehicle stopped, general check, quick licence check, random breath test.  1552: Back On patrol.  1554: Vehicle stopped and checked a suspicious vehicle in a car park.  Male saw police and walked away from vehicle.  Established it was a homeless man living out of car.  1555: Suspicious activity, report of a male with a torch looking through bushes in Hoppers Crossing. Attended the area minutes later, patrolled around the area, and could not see the male subject.  1610: Back on patrol.  1613: Vehicle stopped & checked.  Out of area registered vehicle ‚Äì turned out driver was trying to find an address for a Gumtree purchase.  1617: Back on patrol.  1623: Checked a vehicle registration on a suspicious vehicle ‚Äì owner flagging for a warrant.  Vehicle stopped out the back of Woolworths Tarneit ‚Äì male arrested and taken to the station where he was processed on his warrant.  1710: Clear the station and convey the warrant holder back to his car.  1723: Patrolled Ecoville Park in Tarneit, ongoing reports of anti-social activities.  1730: Clearing the park, no activity to report.  1730: Report of a explosion in Altona Meadows, normally covered by Hobsons Bay, but they were running short of patrol crews, so we made our way there.   Half way there we were cancelled, as a police unit was arriving on scene.  1738: Werribee Railway Station, for a dispute.  Making our way there was advised that PSO are on scene and require no further assistance.  1800: Vehicle stop in Songlark Cres Werribee.  Checked driver and vehicle ‚Äì no issues.  1837: Report of a drug overdose ‚Äì call by the ambulance to assist police re the level of violence.   Arrive on scene to protect the ambulance whilst they treated the man.  He was conveyed to hospital.    1900: Back on patrol.  1905: Stopped at a Subway store for a quick dinner.   Engaged in conversation with a patron.  1915: Dinner - eating in the patrol van.  1919: Vehicle check near Woolworths Tarneit ‚Äì vehicle had suspended registration and a suspended driver.  Processed the driver to appear in court at a later date.  Drove the man home.  Finished off dinner.     1939: Vehicle Collision ‚Äì Greave Street North Werribee: vehicle v motor cycle.   Motor cycle tried to undertake a car as it legally turned into drive way.  Motor cyclist taken to hospital.  Processed scene.  Motor bike rider will have to answer charges of unregistered motor cycle, learner rider ride high powered motor cycle, careless driving.  2000: Monitoring a job where other crews are chasing a thief who stole a chicken from the super market.     2020: Clear from the collision.  2021: Report of an assault in Hoppers Crossing.  On arrival, it we established it was a road rage incident.  Couldn‚Äôt locate the unknown offender.  Victim did not want to make a report and was rather uncooperative with police.  2050: Clearing from the assault report.  2119: Report of a disturbance at Wyndham Leisure Centre. On arrival couldn‚Äôt find anyone.    2142: Report of a burglary in Hoppers Crossing.   Attended and investigate establishing some young kids on a roof.   Kids ran off upon police arrival.  2205: Cleared from above job and patrolled back towards station.  2220: Back at station and completed reports.  2300: Complete duties, hand back equipment and out the door at 2315.
Pictorial Review of the Wyndham North 303, day 21/11/2017

Wyndham Police would like to remind the community to stay safe and consider these tips when in public.   If possible, try to keep anything of value hidden from view while you‚Äôre in public.   Hold your head high and stay aware of your surroundings and if possible, walk on the footpath facing oncoming traffic.   Be observant and if anyone appears suspicious or tries to distract you, keep a safe distance.   Don‚Äôt leave home without your mobile phone and keep one ear free at all times when listening with headphones.   If you need emergency assistance call Triple Zero (000) and to report suspicious behaviour call local police 8734 1100 or Crime Stoppers 1800 333 000.

PLEASE BE AWARE!  Recently the Peninsula and in particular, elderly people have been targeted for a Telstra phone scam. Two separate attempts of this scam were identified over the weekend.  The victims are called by scammers claiming that they are from Telstra and required passwords and log in details for computers as there are 'issues with their internet' (or similar).  Once access to the computers has been obtained, the scammers are accessing bank accounts, etc. The scammers are also known to ask the victims to withdraw large amounts of money or to buy iTunes cards and send them to overseas addresses.   If you think you have been targeted for a scam you can report the scam to Scamwatch. For more information on up-to-date scams visit https://www.scamwatch.gov.au/

SOBERING UP TAKES TIME  On Sunday morning Hastings Police intercepted a P Plate driver at 10.00am for a routine licence check.  The P Plate driver had been drinking the previous evening and blew .076 when tested losing his licence for 6 months on the spot.  After a heavy night of drinking, it can take more than 18 hours for your blood alcohol concentration to get back to zero. Be safe and plan your travels accordingly.

DRIVER USES MUD TO PARTLY COVER NUMBER PLATES  Somerville HWP members come across all sorts of weird and wonderful things whilst out on patrol. Just after 7.30pm last Sunday members intercepted a silver Holden Astra driving along the Westernport Highway in Skye. They were suspicious of the vehicle as its front and rear registration plates were covered in mud, whilst the rest of the car was fairly clean. The 34 y.o. male driver from Pakenham at first told police that the muddy road he had just driven down must have been the culprit, but when police ran checks and found out the car was unregistered and that he was unlicensed, he admitted to strategically arranging the mud over his plates to try and avoid detection.   The driver will be charged on summons to appear at the Dandenong Magistrates‚Äô Court at a later date, and Acting Sgt Paul HOLTZINGER said ‚ÄúThis reinforces the fact that those thinking of driving whilst unlicensed or unregistered are highly likely to be caught.‚Äù  (Author: VP30339)

At approximately 2pm, members of the Community Safety Team observed a vehicle with no registration plates driving on Derrimut Road.  Police attempted to intercept the vehicle which failed to stop, driving erratically through the car park of Werribee Plaza.  The hapless occupants left the still running vehicle and ran from the scene, leaving behind identification and mobile phones.  The vehicle was impounded at a cost of over $1000. The occupants will be interviewed at a later date

A dead whale has washed up near Sorrento Beach at Jubilee Point.  The whale is 14 metres in length and washed up onto a low tide rock platform at the base of the Jubilee Point Cliffs, Mornington Peninsula National Park. It is currently intact and leeching blood from wounds around its mouth, possibly made by shark scavenging.  The whale has been confirmed as a Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) that is male and is believed to be a sub-adult. The whale is on a section of the coast that not accessible to the public. DELWP and Parks Victoria are working together to remove the whale with police in attendance.  DELWP PortPhillip Parks Victoria

TECH SAVVY CAR THIEVES  Victoria Police is aware the existence of relay devices being used to commit vehicle theft and has been monitoring the criminal use of this technology overseas ‚Äì such as in the UK and Europe. Police will continue to monitor the issue however we have not seen this occurring here in Victoria  There are a few things the community can to do to avoid becoming a victim of theft. This includes:  Secure your vehicle - ensure that your vehicle is locked before you walk away   Valuables and gifts should not be left in your vehicle any longer than necessary  If you do have to transport valuables, they should be stored in the glove box or boot   Park in a well-lit area ‚Äì thieves do not want to be caught breaking into cars, so increase the risk that others will detect them.
The Wyndham Community Safety Team are out at the Manor Lakes Shopping Centre.   Come and say hello, they will be there until 2pm!

THE TRAVELLING SCAM-MAN  Mornington Peninsula residents are being asked to be very careful if they are approached by people purporting to be tradesmen offering discounted work. This could include painting, roof repairs, driveway repairs and other similar work.   There are unfortunately people who are doing sub-standard work, and charging considerably more than the value of the work being quoted. Unfortunately, these people are known to prey on the elderly and vulnerable, and can be very assertive with members of the public, offering one-off sale prices or heavily discounted prices due to job cancellations or for other reasons.  Historically, these people target our areas over the summer and there have been some reports of this already occurring. Unless you are absolutely certain that you are dealing with qualified and reputable tradespeople/companies, our advice is to be careful.  If anyone is approached in these circumstances, our advice is to kindly refuse the work. If these people are persistent, do not engage with them and call 000, Crimestoppers on 1800 333 000 or Consumer Affairs Victoria on 1300 558 181.

MAJOR DRINK & DRUG DRIVING OPERATIONS THIS WEEKEND - Frankston & Mornington Peninsula  Somerville HWP would like to advise that they will be conducting a number of large operations this weekend targeting drivers affected by alcohol and/or drugs. Booze Buses and patrol car random breath testing sites will be set up on main arterials and back roads at various locations throughout the Frankston & Mornington Peninsula Council areas, so the chances of being pulled over and tested are very high. Please think about what you're risking and do not get behind the wheel whilst affected by drugs/alcohol.   (Author: VP30339)

TRAINING STASH  Even when Victoria Police are conducting training, they are still making significant arrests. Dedicated investigations have led to the arrest of more than a dozen offenders involved in separate carjacking offences across the Darebin, Whittlesea and Banyule areas.   Police have zero tolerance for this kind of offending which can understandably cause harm or distress to victims.   In recent months, police have arrested 17 alleged offenders with 11 of those currently remanded in custody.   Many of these offences have been opportunistic and there is no group or particular demographic consistent amongst the offenders.   While these carjackings are relatively rare and often targeted at those involved in other criminal activities, the recent arrests in relation to carjackings are a reminder for the community to remain vigilant when it comes to personal safety.   Personal safety and awareness should always be a high priority and this is no different when driving a car.   When driving you should consider driving with the doors locked and car secure.

*** MOVEMBER ***  Members from the Geelong Police station took up the Movember Challenge raising just shy of $1200 for a great cause.  As part of the challenge, Police Custody Officer Riley ELLETT called for donations to shave off his moustache. This call to arms resulted in Riley personally raising $301.  Another $150 was raised through the running of a BBQ held celebrate the end of Movember and International Men‚Äôs Day (19/11). AFFRAY AND ASSAULTS AT THE FRANKSTON FORESHORE  On Thursday the 30th of November, 2017, detectives from Frankston CIU charged a 21 year old Cranbourne man and two men from Frankston North, aged 26 & 29, in relation to an affray and assaults at the Frankston Foreshore.    It is alleged that during the incident, which occurred at approximately 7.45PM, three youths were thrown into Kananook Creek, sustaining minor injuries and damage to mobile phones.    Two members of the public came to the assistance of the youths, and it is alleged that the males then assaulted both of them, resulting in one male victim being transported to hospital.    Police would like to thank the public for the assistance they have provided so far, including witness statements and video footage.   If anyone else believes they can assist with video footage of the incident, please contact investigators from the Frankston CIU on (03) 9784 5590 or Crimestoppers on 1800 333 000.

EVEN IN THE RAIN WE WILL CATCH YOU  At 1130 today Westgate Highway Patrol conducting unrelated business in Hoppers Crossing saw a suspicious looking car drive by.  Checking the registration, revealed the plates were stolen.  An attempted to intercept was made, and due to the dangerous driving by the vehicle of interest, attempts to intercept were discontinued.    As this was occurring the subject vehicle came to a halt due to mechanical issues and the driver fled on foot over back fences.  A police response was called in, and a male subject was captured and arrested about one kilometer away.  Currently in custody on charges of:  * Theft of number plates * Evade Police * Drive in a dangerous manner * Disqualified driving * Unregistered motor vehicle

$600 SCAMMED AND GONE!!!  A scam has cost a local woman $600 after she was duped into buying, and providing the codes from several iTunes cards.   The Carrum Downs woman received a phone call from someone claiming to be from Telstra. They advised her that her computer needed fixing after being hacked and to do so, they needed $600 worth of iTunes cards as payment and access to her home computer. The victim purchased the iTunes cards and also provided bank account details.  The scammers then told her they‚Äôd ‚Äòaccidentally‚Äô deposited money into her bank account and asked her to return $2000 to them and to not to discuss this with anyone.   The victim realised something was amiss and sought advice. She was able to get in touch with the real Telstra and make sure no software had been installed on her computer by the hackers. She also had to close her bank account to ensure it hadn‚Äôt been compromised.   Police encourage members of the community to be aware of scams such as this. Police also ask the public to warn members of their family that may not see warnings such as this online; especially the elderly in the community.  Police advise members of the public that;  - Unless a purchase is from an iTunes store, iBooks or Apple music store- there is NO reason you‚Äôd need to make a payment via iTunes Gift Cards.  - Beware of ‚Äòcold callers‚Äô especially if they ask for personal details.  - If you receive any phone calls about issues with your computer, seek independent advice from reputed computer repairers or from your internet/ phone provider.  - Don‚Äôt accept where someone is from simply because they tell you so over the phone.  - Calls can be easily diverted through local servers to appear that they have originated from Australia, even if the caller is overseas.  - If it sounds suspicious, it probably is. Make enquiries with the company directly, sourcing the phone numbers yourself and not relying on what the caller has told you over the phone. Scammers networks can be very well run and include numerous people in an attempt to appear authentic.  Apple provides the following information about scams linked to iTunes cards; https://support.apple.com/en-au/itunes-gift-card-scams  If you think you have been the victim of an scam such as this, please lodge a report with ACORN (Australian Cybercrime Online Reporting Network) at www.acorn.gov.au.

GEELONG POLICE CRIME PREVENTION OFFICE LEAD THE WAY IN CRIME PREVENTION  Victoria Police Geelong Crime Prevention Office along with the City of Greater Geelong launched the Pakington Street Traders Association (Geelong West and Newtown) on 5 December 2017 at Busters Bar & Grill in Pakington Street.  The launch was attended by the COGG, DOJR, Victoria Government and local retailers/traders.   Inspector Darlow stated ‚Äúthe establishment of the Traders Association will enable a direct communication link and support between Police and retailers to inform them of relevant issues and crime prevention initiatives to ensure the vibrant precinct remains safe and secure  It also provides operational police members contact details of a specific retailer after hours if operational necessity requires it‚Äù.    A Public Safety Infrastructure Grant of $10,000 has been approved to develop ‚ÄòTraders Kits‚Äô which will provide traders with information on how to make their business safe and secure in a dynamic and changing environment.     Leading Senior Constable King from the Crime Prevention Office officially launched the ‚ÄúNo Cash on Premises‚Äù initiative with the Pakington Street Traders Association which was first implemented into Bellarine (Ocean Grove Traders Association) in February 2016 with much success.  Inspector Darlow stated ‚Äúthe practise of daily takings and floats being left within retail premises overnight was seen as a major causation of offences in the Burglary offence category.  This strategy involves the education of correct money handling by retailers where by "no cash is left on premises" after hours and that the cash register draw is left open and money tray is visibly placed along with a sign indicating that there is no money left on the premises.  Since its inception into the Bellarine, there has been no commercial burglary targeting cash at retail outlets.  This will be one in a range of initiatives that will be introduced into the Pakington Street retail precinct and we look forward to working with the Pakington Street Traders Association and other partners to ensuring this remains an attractive, safe and vibrant location to visit‚Äù.

COFFEE WITH A COP IN WAURN PONDS  Waurn Ponds police are inviting members of the public to join them for an informal cuppa and a chat on Wednesday 13 December.  Coffee with a Cop is an initiative supported by Waurn Ponds Police, working in partnership with the Waurn Ponds Shopping Centre, which provides an opportunity for community members to meet their local police.  This is the first time Waurn Ponds police have taken part in the initiative, giving people the chance to engage with them and strengthen relationships within the community.   Acting Sergeant Mark Thomas said he hopes that people will take up this opportunity to come down and speak to police about community issues in a neutral and informal space.   ‚ÄúThe aim of this initiative is to create a community where people feel safe and connected.   ‚ÄúWe want to encourage everyone join us for a coffee and discuss issues which are important to them.  ‚ÄúWe are here to provide advice about crime prevention, local issues and any concerns in our community.‚Äù  ‚ÄúBuilding a positive relationship with the Waurn Ponds community is a high priority for us and we hope to see many of you there next Wednesday.‚Äù  Community members are invited to join Waurn Ponds Police at the Waurn Ponds Shopping Centre at Coffee Hit on Wednesday 13 December at 10am.

BE AWARE of the ATO SCAM ... Don't fall for it!!  Yet another scammer has been caught on tape attempting to con another Australian out of their hard-earned money.  How to protect yourself from scams:     If you receive a phone call or email out of the blue from someone claiming to be from the Commonwealth DPP or Australian Taxation Office telling you about an arrest warrant, hang up.     If you have any doubts about the identity of any caller who claims to represent a government department, contact the body directly.     Don't rely on numbers, email addresses or websites provided by the caller ‚Äî find them through an independent source such as a phone book or online search.     Never send money via wire transfer to anyone you do not know or trust.     Never give your personal, credit card or online account details over the phone unless you made the call and the phone number came from a trusted source.     If you think you have provided your account details to a scammer, contact your bank or financial institution immediately.  Source: Scamwatch, ACCC

HIGHWAY PATROL UPDATE  The Somerville HWP Nightshift unit had a busy shift on Saturday night / Sunday morning whilst patrolling the area in an unmarked car. Their evening included;  ‚Ä¢ At 10.30 pm they were overtaken at high speed on Frankston-Dandenong Rd Carrum Downs by a Suzuki GSXR motorbike which they then clocked at 118 km/h in the 80 zone. The 34 y.o. male rider from Noble Park's licence was suspended for 6 mths along with a $595 fine and 6 demerit points.   ‚Ä¢ At 2.00 am they were overtaken on Western Port Hwy Skye by a silver Commodore which then turned onto Hall Rd and accelerated to 128 km/h in the 80 zone heading towards Carrum Downs. The vehicle was impounded for a minimum of 30 days with a release fee of $1005. The 20 y.o. male driver from Carrum Downs was a red 'P' plater who was already on his demerit point bond. He will be summonsed to appear in the Frankston Magistrates' Court where he faces 12 months loss of licence and a fine.     ‚Ä¢ At 4.20 am they saw a Holden Cruze travelling quickly along Lyrebird Dr Carrum Downs and measured it's speed at approximately 100 km/h in the 50 zone. After going around the wrong side of a roundabout, the 27 y.o. male driver from Carrum Downs was breath tested and blew 0.121%. His car was impounded for a minimum 30 days with a release fee of $961. His licence was suspended on the spot and he will also be summonsed to appear in Frankston Magistrates' Court, to face a minimum 12 months loss of licence and a fine.       Most of the time we patrol in marked police cars for high visibility, but sometimes we don't.  Is that car up ahead or behind of you an unmarked police car? If you're obeying the road rules then it doesn't matter.  (Author: VP30339)

DANGEROUS DRUG DRIVER ON PENINSULA LINK ‚Äì Intercepted by Somerville HWP  Somerville HWP members were dealing with a minor accident on Peninsula Link near Skye Rd just after midday yesterday (Sunday), when a concerned motorist stopped and alerted them to a driver coming along Pen Link who was falling asleep at the wheel and veering all over the road. This vehicle then passed by the members heading South and exited at Skye Rd, where it was then intercepted at a service station. The 38 y.o. male driver from Tyabb was a disqualified learner driver, who then tested positive for methylamphetamine ("Ice"). He also  said he had taken buprenorphine ("Bupe"), which is a medication used to treat opiate addiction. The Ford sedan he was driving was impounded for a minimum of 30 days with a release fee of $1005, and he will face Frankston Magistrates' Court at a later date for charges including Driving Whilst Disqualified & Drug Driving.    If you see things like this on the road, please alert police as soon as possible. You just might stop a serious accident from occurring.

RED HSV GTS CAR ACCIDENT ON BUNGOWER RD SATURDAY EVENING ‚Äì Appeal for Witnesses  Somerville HWP are appealing for witnesses to a collision which occurred just before 8pm on Saturday night in Bungower Rd Moorooduc, near Peninsula Link. The driver of a red 2010 model HSV GTS sedan travelling West along Bungower Rd appears to have done an extensive burnout prior to losing control, over-correcting and flipping the car into a ditch. Three males were in the car at the time, one of whom was transported to hospital for observation.  If you saw this vehicle in the area prior to the collision, or witnessed the collision itself, please contact the investigator Constable Chris SPERO at Somerville HWP via email christopher.spero@police.vic.gov.au or via CrimeStoppers Ph: 1800 333000.

Don‚Äôt let opportunistic thieves ruin your festive season!  To help prevent your vehicle being targeted;  - try to park it in a secure garage, with all valuables removed.  - park off the street in your driveway if you don‚Äôt have a garage - park in a well-lit area ‚Äì thieves do not want to be caught breaking into cars, so increase the risk that others will detect them - lock your car ‚Äì always physically check it is locked, even when parking at home or just leaving your car for a moment - lock external tool boxes and equipment if they can‚Äôt be removed  - secure licence plates with one way screws (these are available from hardware stores) - install a car alarm  If you see something suspicious, contact 000 or Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000

We held our Community Forum on Tuesday night.  We had very good attendance despite this busy time of year.  Attendees were entertained by Thomastown West Primary School Band. We also heard from Local Area Commander Inspector Andrew Falconer, Cathy Rhodes from Crime Stoppers and Adam Haliwell from the Crime Statistic Agendy.  Attendees were then were led into a whole room discussion session and used Dot-mocracy to identify issues raised for greater discussion.    Whittlesea Uni Hill Conference Centre 61 registered attendees with 48 people attending on the night Top 3 community issues  More than 40 people attended and the top three community issues they identified were gendered violence, mental health and drug and alcohol. ******BEWARE OF SCAMMERS*******  Police in Latrobe are currently seeing an increase of scams involving itunes Gift Cards.  Reports to Scamwatch show there are three common scam examples the ACCC is currently seeing where scammers are demanding iTunes gift cards as payment:  Tax scams ‚Äì the scammer pretends to be from the Australian Taxation Office and claim there is a warrant out for their victim‚Äôs arrest. If the victim doesn‚Äôt pay an immediate ‚Äòfine‚Äô using iTunes gift cards, the scammer claims police will come and handcuff them.  Catch-a-hacker scam ‚Äì scammers pretending to be Telstra will ask their victim to help them catch a ‚Äòhacker‚Äô who‚Äôs trying to get into their PC or smart devices. They‚Äôll use this sham story to get the victim to buy iTunes cards as a ‚Äòtrap‚Äô for catching the hacker. Unfortunately the scammer will quickly get the serial numbers for those gift cards and sell them before the victim realises they‚Äôve been duped.  Centrelink scams ‚Äì the scammer pretends to be from Centrelink and tells their victim they‚Äôre entitled to an additional payment, such as for their pension, and that they need to pay a ‚Äòrelease fee‚Äô in iTunes gift cards to receive the payment.  Report scams to www.scamwatch.gov.au

A message from Shane Smith, local area commander for Cardinia.   I‚Äôm pleased to tell you the latest figures show the crime rate in Cardinia has decreased by 16.9%, thanks to significant decreases in high-volume crimes such as burglaries, thefts and robberies.   While it‚Äôs pleasing to see a drop in these crime categories, rest assured we are not complacent. Police across Cardinia will continue to work hard to prevent, deter, investigate and arrest offenders in order to keep people and their property safe.   We have and will continue to maintain a strong focus on crime categories that significantly impact community safety such as assault and related offences (down 10%), burglary/break and enter (down 16.9%), robbery (down 30.3%), theft (down 18.6%).   Some categories of crime have increased, including cultivate or manufacture drugs (up 31.3%) and weapons-related offences (up 23.9%), which is primarily due to police activity and enforcement as we continue to arrest and charge offenders for these types of offences.   I‚Äôd like to thank the community for your ongoing support and remind everyone that prevention is the key. Lock your vehicle when unattended and don‚Äôt leave valuable items visible to passers-by. This type of theft is mostly opportunistic so can be prevented by simple security measures.   If you see something suspicious, say something. If the matter is urgent call 000 or report to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.   Police are out in force on our roads from today and right through the holiday period so please stay safe and have a happy Christmas and New Year.

Christmas greetings to all of our Eyewatch friends from the Frankston Inspector‚Äôs Office,                      Following a busy and productive year for your local police, I have some really good crime statistics to pass on to everyone: Robbery (theft with violence) in Frankston is down 34%. Burglaries have also fallen 14.4%. The one we all want to see drop is the aggravated home burglaries and we‚Äôre pleased to see that we‚Äôve seen a decrease of 15.7%.   Whilst the falling crime data is a real positive, the reality is that every offence committed means there is another victim in our community and in our eyes that‚Äôs one too many. We‚Äôll continue to do all we can to prevent and disrupt crime.  You can assist us by: Taking greater guardianship of your property.  Lock your car and remember that wallets, handbags and laptops love to be inside your house and not left in the car.    Ask, could you get into your house if you accidently locked yourself out?  If the answer is yes then it‚Äôs time to improve security for your greatest asset, your family!  Remember that thieves are generally a pretty lazy lot, so if you take away their opportunity then you will be helping us greatly.       If you see something suspicious, say something. If the matter is urgent call 000 or make a report to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.

Please be aware of an email scam targeting CityLink account holders that is currently doing the rounds.  The scam email is requesting payment for a CityLink Toll Invoice to prevent it from being referred to Victoria Police:  If you receive a CityLink Toll Invoice email claiming to be from CityLink, check to ensure it does not contain any of these distinguishing features.  * from an email address of citylink.digital@citylinkres.com * the Toll Invoice number ends in 20887 * the amount owing is $28.34  Do not click any links within the email https://www.citylink.com.au/help/security-and-fraud/security-and-scam-alerts/current-scams

In the last 12 months, there's been over 90,000 family violence offences in Victoria. A ground-breaking project is changing the way Victoria Police responds to these incidents.  The Enhancing Police Responses to Family Violence project is a joint initiative between Victoria Police, Forensicare, Medicare Local and Swinburne University established in late 2014 to improve family violence risk assessment and management.   Part of the project has involved working with Swinburne to redevelop the family violence risk assessment tool to create a new actuarial risk assessment instrument, the VP-SAFvR, to be piloted in the Police Service Areas of Maribyrnong, Hobson‚Äôs Bay and Wyndham.   The new tool is having a significant impact on the response, risk assessment and management of family violence incidents in the pilot area since being introduced in June 2016.   Crime statistics agency data shows a 10% reduction in family violence-related serious assaults, a 14% reduction in repeat affected family members and a 16% reduction in repeat respondents.   The project was recently announced as a gold award winner in the police-led category of the 2017 Australian Crime and Violence Prevention Awards.

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Shepparton Police Service Area
Post Message: DISCONNECTING CAN BE HARD... but what are you risking?

Launching 'Operation Roadwise' this week... The Ballarat area has seen a large increase in road trauma over the past 3 months so there will be an elevated road policing presence during the Festive Season leading into the New Year.   There has also been an increase in local drivers being detected driving under the influence of alcohol. This represents a significant risk to community safety and police are calling on people to plan ahead and organise alternate transport over the Festive Season if required.  At a blood-alcohol level of 0.05 to 0.08, your ability to judge distances is reduced, reactions are slower and concentration span is shorter.  At 0.08 drivers are five times more likely to have an accident.  Stay alert, stay sober, stay within the limit and stay alive - Wishing you a Safe & Merry Christmas and New Year from the Ballarat Police Division.

POLICE BLITZ WHITTLESEA ROADS   Whittlesea police will flood the roads across the next week in an effort to reduce road trauma in the lead-up to Christmas Day.   Whether you are attending the office Christmas party, or simply celebrating the season with loved ones, police are urging all road users to be responsible and safe.   Senior Sergeant Glenn Parker said catastrophic consequences were never far away whenever people engaged in unsafe behaviour on the road.   ‚ÄúWe know there is an increased risk taking on our roads around licensed premises in Whittlesea this time of year,‚Äù he said.   ‚ÄúAs such, we will deploy marked and unmarked police cars across the area in an effort to minimise road trauma.    ‚ÄúThe hope is that the only thing our police will see is safe, responsible behaviour.‚Äù   Police will target the main causes of fatalities and serious injuries including excessive speed, mobile phone use and driver distraction, seatbelts, fatigue and drink and drug drivers.   Across Victoria over the past five years, 59 people have been killed and over 1500 people seriously injured on the roads during the Christmas and New Year period.   ‚ÄúKeep any eye on your friends and loved ones to ensure they are primarily thinking of safety whenever they use our roads,‚Äù Snr Sgt Parker said.   ‚ÄúEven a momentary lapse in judgment can result in an empty seat at the Christmas table next week.‚Äù

ATTUNGA GROVE, WERRIBEE INCIDENT.  The Werribee and Wyndham North Police would like to reassure the community that an incident that occured in Attunga Grove, Werribee in the early hours of today (20/12/17) is being fully investigated by the Wyndham Criminal Investigation Unit. I would also like to reassure you that appropriate levels of patrols are being conducted to deter, detect and investigate any incidents reported at any time of the day and night.  These patrols are being conducted utilising our uniform members, Detectives, Highway Patrol and other specialist units (Mounted Branch, K9 and PolAir). A 28 year old St Albans man will be spending Christmas in custody after appearing at the Sunshine Magistrates Court on a number of serious traffic related charges.  These charges were as a result of Operation AFECTAR-2017 which is targetting those involved in Illegal Intentional High Risk Driving (HOON) events in the North Western & North Metropolitan Suburbs of Melbourne.  The male plead Guilty to being the organiser of 10 illegal street meetings and was sentenced to a 12 month custodial sentence with an non parole period of 6 months. He was also fined $2000 and had his licence suspended for a further period of 12 months. His vehicle and mobile phone were forfeited to the crown.  A second male from Delahey who was also involved in arranging the events was sentenced to 14 months in a Youth Training Facility.

THE VESPER BANDIT  20 December 2017: 1900hrs  A wanted suspect is now on Remand till late January 2018, after leading police from the Wyndham area, on a low speed pursuit through several Wyndham suburbs.  The suspect was spotted on a distinct Vesper in Old Geelong Road Hoppers Crossing, at 7pm on Wednesday.   Police indicated for him to pull over, and he has chosen to evade officers.  During the course of the pursuit, multiple additional offending was detected. (On footpath, into oncoming traffic).   A tactical plan was put in place bringing the rider to a halt, without incident, where he was taken into custody in Wyndham Vale.  The 31 year old Wyndam Vale man was charged with 24 offences ranging from several outstanding thefts that he was wanted for, and previous evade police incidents and several driving charges.    Police held him in custody till he faced court today, where he was denied bail and remanded in custody to a further date in late January.  The Vesper is now in the police impound yard waiting forfeiture and is no longer a danger to our community.  (pictured - not our man).

Police are out in force in the area tonight checking people and vehicles in an effort to detect, disrupt and deter offending and anti-social behaviour. Operation Nightlight is large contingent of police deployed in the Wyndham area.   In the first few hours of this operation, police have detected a number of offences, including:  -9 people in one car (vehicle impounded, three unrestrained children), -one male wanted on two warrants who was driving whilst disqualified (vehicle also impounded), and to be interviewed for breach of intervention order, -2 for drink-driving (one impounded after blowing 0.145)  (Pictured: one impound, one waiting for second impound tow truck)

I would like to wish everyone a safe and happy festive season. It‚Äôs been a great pleasure to bring you information on our Knox PSA Eyewatch page and it has been wonderful to watch our online community grow to over 10,000 followers! With the launch of the Maroondah Eyewatch page this month we now have 3 Eyewatch pages to reach all residents and community members within Eastern Region Division 2.  We‚Äôve had some great results over the last 12 months with substantial reductions across crime against the person and crime against property categories.  Throughout 2017 we have increased the number of police members working nightshifts to ensure an enhanced response to emerging crime trends, and we‚Äôve undertaken a significant number of local crime and road policing operations.  We won‚Äôt be resting over the holidays ‚Äì more operations are scheduled for next year, including plain clothed operations targeting public transport and retail precincts, and throughout the holiday period we will be highly visible with random preliminary breath testing sites throughout the Knox response zone ‚ÄìBayswater, Boronia, Ferntree Gully, Knox, Lysterfield, Rowville, Scoresby, The Basin, Upper Ferntree Gully, Wantirna & Wantirna South.   As the summer season progresses, so too does our emergency management preparedness.  Wherever you may be enjoying a well-deserved Xmas break, please remember on days of high fire risk, it is better to leave early and go to a safe place, than to leave exit plans until the last minute.  If you are going away for the holidays, make sure that your home is locked, that you‚Äôve told someone where you are going, usually a friend, neighbour, or relative, so they can maintain some security on your residence whilst you are away. Theft from motor car remains an ongoing issue in our area ‚Äì please ensure you remove all valuables and secure your car in a garage if possible. If you are going away and leaving your car at home, please ensure it is locked and that your keys are hidden.  The holiday period is a busy time, please do your part to help people travel safely to be with their friends and family ‚Äì I ask that you be patient and mindful of other users on our roads. If you‚Äôre going to drink, plan not to drive and plan your transport options in advance.  On behalf of the Knox Eyewatch team, we look forward to interacting with you via our Facebook page more in 2018 ‚Äì together we can make a difference!  Inspector Helen Sattler Local Area Commander - Knox Police Service Area

ABSOLUTELY UTE-LESS IN FRANKSTON  Somerville Highway Patrol members put the brakes on a ute that was allegedly speeding along the Peninsula Link overnight.  The blue Toyota was detected travelling at 156km/h in Frankston about 2.55am.  They attempted to intercept the vehicle before it reached speeds of 160km/h.  The driver, a 52-year-old Somerville man, was intercepted shortly after, with his ute impounded on the spot for 30 days.  He is also expected to be charged on summons with speeding.  The intercept forms part of the Roadwise Campaign, a statewide operation aimed at reducing road trauma and improving road user behaviour.    The operation, which started on 15 December, will run throughout the high-risk summer period to 7 January 2018.  During this time there will be an increased focus by police on the main causes of fatalities and serious injuries, including excessive speed, driver distraction, seatbelt non-compliance, fatigue and drink and drug drivers.  The operation involves a response from all available personnel including local road policing units, general duties, other operational policing units and centralised resources from Road Policing Command.

Geelong Highway Patrol received a welcome and timely addition to their Highway Patrol Car fleet today with the arrival of a Mercedes-AMG E43 sedan in full Highway Patrol livery. The vehicle, nicknamed the ‚ÄúGuardian‚Äù, apart from being a fully operational Highway Patrol vehicle is a rolling example of some of the most advanced safety features that have ever been fitted to a road going vehicle.   Two years ago, Victoria Police formed a partnership with Mercedes Benz to promote the future of vehicle safety. If every vehicle in Australia was fitted with the technology found in this vehicle road trauma could be reduced by a third overnight. To achieve this in the future, we need to change the way industry and households purchase a vehicle and start making safety a standard feature, not an optional extra.  Mercedes Benz has loaned the vehicle to Victoria Police to promote the new technologies and help us drive down road trauma across our state.   The Guardian has already been put to use and is already on patrol.  The vehicle will be on patrol over the Christmas and New Year periods in the Geelong, Bellarine, Surfcoast and Colac areas conducting traffic patrols and assisting with significant traffic operations.  Geelong Highway Patrol urge you to take care this holiday period.  Don‚Äôt drive impaired by alcohol, drugs or lack of sleep, make sure you and all your vehicle occupants wear a suitable seatbelt or restraint, observe the posted limits and avoid distraction by putting that phone or electronic device away and out of sight.   247 people have lost their lives on Victoria‚Äôs roads so far this year.  Although less than the 282 that lost their lives last year.  Police are acutely aware it‚Äôs still at least 247 Christmas‚Äôs that are likely to be ruined for families due to Road Trauma.  Stay Safe and Drive Carefully.  Arriving late is better than not arriving at all.
It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas,  Cops out a lot more, But the prettiest sight to see is your loved ones that will be, On your own front door üéÖüèΩüéÑ

It's a Christmas Miracle!  A 30 year old male from Werribee who featured on our Warrant Wednesday posts in September 2017, has been arrested tonight on 8 warrants, by eagle-eyed members patrolling the streets. Despite promising police, commenting on his own publicised mug shot, that he'll come in and sort it out, he didn't.  He is currently is custody whilst bail/remand is considered.

Police will be out and about this holiday period, however burglaries do occur so it pays to be vigilant. An empty house can potentially become a target. Take some simple steps to help protect your property.  - Lock & secure all windows and doors - Ensure alarms are activated - Notify neighbours of your absence & have mail collected - If cars are left at home, secure them. Never leave car keys in the home.  Report suspicious activity to local police or Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000. In an emergency call 000 (Triple zero).

Are you heading off on holidays today?   Greensborough Highway Patrol and our State Highway Patrol Units will be working right through this holiday period targeting the fatal four contributing factors to collisions speed, drug/drink driving, fatigue and seat belts.    Speed is a proven to increase your chances of having a collision.  Better to be late than not getting there at all.    Drink/Drug driving is a major contributory factor to road crashes and road deaths.   If you going to a party and plan to indulge in a drink or two don‚Äôt drive. Stay the night or plan a safe alternative to get home such as a cab or designated driver who does not drink.  Don‚Äôt  forget that even in the morning after you have slept you could still be over the limit.  The same applies to drugs.  Wearing your seat belt reduces your risk of dying or being seriously injured in a collision so always buckle up. Also, make sure young passengers are buckled into appropriate safety seats. Fatigue is the hidden killer.  Please don‚Äôt try to drive if  you feel your eyes shutting.  A microsleep could kill you or others.   Take turns driving if there is another licensed person in the vehicle.  Take regular breaks if you are on a long journey.  Motorcyclists should ride wearing protective clothing.  Be aware of debris on the road and soft shoulders on rural highays.  Ride within the limits of your ability. If your towing a caravan or trailer ensure it is correctly coupled to your vehicle and that any load is secured correctly by an appropriate method of restraint.  Make sure that your vehicle is mechanically safe and legally roadworthy.   Enjoy your holidays and please drive safely.

POLICE AND MENTAL HEALTH CLINICIANS WORKING TOGETHER TO ASSIST THE COMMUNITY.  Police from Westgate Division and Mental Health Clinicians from Werribee Mercy Hospital have been working together since January 2017 to assist community members suffering from mental health issues. The project is referred to as the Westgate PACER (Police and Clinician Emergency Response) and involves a uniformed police member and qualified mental health clinician working together 7 days per week during the afternoon/evening.  The primary role of the PACER unit is to assist front line members attending tasks where people are exhibiting suicidal behaviour or suffering from some sort of mental health crisis.  This allows for the person in crisis to be given expert assistance and treatment, but also allows for the front line uniform members to be relieved to attend other tasks increasing community safety. The project is ongoing and has assisted in forming an extremely strong working relationship between the Health Services and Victoria Police, as well as assisting the community as a whole.  Acting Senior Sergeant Jason Forster

Post Message: COMMUNITY DEMONSTRATES MORE CHRISTMAS SPIRIT THAN THIEF   A lack of Christmas spirit remedied by a show of community support.  The below motor cycle was to be a Christmas present for a Benalla boy until stolen on the 23/12/17.    It was stored in a locked shed prior to Christmas in Saleyards Road, Benalla. Police remain focused on the offender.  Any information about the burglary or the dirt bike will be well received.  Please contact Leading Senior Constable Sparkes at Benalla Police on 0357600200.  Alternatively information can be provided via Crimestoppers.  www.crimestoppersvic.com.au  Benalla Ensign Benalla Rural City Council Benalla Thumbs Up/Thumbs Down

A number of people in the Ocean Grove area have recently reported to police that they have received fake $50 notes.   They have believed the notes are fake due to the fact that names are not printed under the pictures on both sides. For example, the name of Edith COWAN has not been under her picture.   Names were not added until after 2002 and the notes are in fact genuine and NOT fake.   If any member of the public is concerned that they are in possession of a fake note, they are advised to firstly attend at a bank to confirm whether the note is genuine or not.   At this stage, Bellarine Police have not taken possession of any fake $50 notes.

North West Metro, Division 5 Highway Patrol members supported by local uniformed staff performed a traffic operation yesterday, post New Year's Eve celebrations in an effort to reduce road trauma across the holiday period.  Local police were tasked to target drink and drug driving, and test as many motorists as possible travelling through the Darebin Police Service area.  As a result of the operation, police identified 11 drivers exceeding 0.05%, 1 drug affected driver, 1 disqualified driver, 2 other traffic offences and impounded 2 vehicles.   Local police are still perplexed that some people still aren't getting the message on road safety #takecareonourroads campaign.   Division 5 members will be continuing their efforts to provide a high visible presence on our roads with a zero tolerance approach to those drink and drug driving.

*** Further Update - Detectives hunt car thieves *** At approximately 4:00am on Tuesday the 7th of November 2017 police allege that a stolen Toyota Hilux was travelling along Boronia Road in Boronia. Police would like to thank the public for their assistance.

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Shepparton Police Service Area
Post Message: Have you been at a Nagambie Lakeside Caravan Park recently?  Nagambie police have charged three youths with numerous offences after they had a very busy time in the early hours of Wednesday 27th December, allegedly stealing property from numerous unlocked cars of holiday makers staying in the park.    Sunglasses, money, gift cards, (probably part of some people's Christmas presents), and an IPhone were amongst the property stolen.  Most of the located stolen property has been returned to their owners, but police still have property they have been unable to locate the owners of.  If you were at the Nagambie Lakeside Caravan Park just after Christmas and are having trouble finding some of your property, contact Leading Senior Constable Dave Duff at Nagambie Police on 5794 2526.  He may be able to help you out.  Always remember, thieves dont take holidays, these three, all aged 16,  were holidaying in the park as well.  Just because you are on holidays, doesn't mean that the usual message of Remove It, Lock It, or Lose It, does not still apply.

Operation Firesetter  Police across Whittlesea will once again be conducting high visibility patrols this bushfire season to help prevent bushfires.   High visibility bushfire arson prevention and detection operations will see dedicated patrols deployed to bushfire arson prone areas this fire season and conduct targeted investigations into buchfire persons of interest until the end of April.  Whilst police will be actively patrolling, the public can play a big part in keeping our community safe. We urge the public to come forward if they see or hear of anyone who just doesn't seem right or is acting suspiciously, and immediately report any suspicious behaviour to police by calling Triple Zero (000).   Alternatively, Crime Stoppers can be called confidentially on 1800 333 000.

With extreme heat conditions forecast for tomorrow additional police members will be patrolling, however you can do your part to help by notifying police of any suspicious activity. If you notice anything suspicious or see someone lighting a fire, please call 000 - do not use this media outlet. Take as much detail as possible & relay that to the operator. If you see something or know something about bushfire arson or reckless fires, say something.

Operation Firesetter - Offenders will feel the heat  Operation Firesetter is a dedicated, high visibility bushfire arson prevention and detection operation focussing on patrolling high risk bushfire areas, crime prevention activities and the management and monitoring or persons of interest.  Whilst local police will be doing all they can to protect the community we urge the public to report any suspicious behaviour immediately to Triple Zero (000). There will be no tolerance for people who recklessly or intentionally cause fires this summer.  Penalties include;  - Recklessly or intentionally causing a bushfire - up to 15 years imrisonment - Discarding burning material including cigarettes, matches etc. or lighting rubbish without a permit - up to $18,500 and/or up to 1 year imrisonment - Light a fire in open air during a period of fire danger - uo to $18,500 and/or up to 1 year imprisonment - Light fire on a day of total fire ban - around $37,000 and/or up to 2 years imprisonment

Our members have got their vehicle aircons set to max as they patrol around today for Operation Firesetter.  The aim of Operation Firesetter is to reduce the occurrence and impact of suspicious, both intentional and reckless, bushfire arson activity during high-risk periods like today.  You can help by please being mindful of your activities during fire danger periods - it could be your actions that result in loss of life or property.  Also, if you see something -  say something.  If you believe a person or vehicle is acting suspicious write down their details (as much as possible) and contact your local police or Crime Stoppers 1800 333 000 - www.crimestoppers.com.au.   vp40485

Post Message: Our members have got their vehicle aircons set to max as they patrol around today for Operation Firesetter.  The aim of Operation Firesetter is to reduce the occurrence and impact of suspicious, both intentional and reckless, bushfire arson activity during high-risk periods like today.  You can help by please being mindful of your activities during fire danger periods - it could be your actions that result in loss of life or property.  Also, if you see something -  say something.  If you believe a person or vehicle is acting suspicious write down their details (as much as possible) and contact your local police or Crime Stoppers 1800 333 000 - www.crimestoppers.com.au.   vp40485

The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a severe weather warning for several parts of the state including Ballarat, with damaging winds expected this afternoon.   Damaging winds averaging 60 to 70 km/h with peak gusts around 90 km/h are possible over parts of the Southwest, Wimmera, Central and West and South Gippsland districts this afternoon and evening with the passage of a cold front.  Winds are expected to ease within an hour of the wind change.  Locations which may be affected include Horsham, Warrnambool, Ballarat, Geelong, Melbourne and Bacchus Marsh.  The warning comes on top of a statewide total fire ban, with the mercury expected to tip 38 degrees in Ballarat later this afternoon.  The State Emergency Service advises that people should:   * Move vehicles under cover or away from trees;   * Secure or put away loose items around your house, yard and balcony;   * Keep clear of fallen power lines

Today is a Total Fire Ban Day, and plain and simple, you are not allowed to light a campfire. Same goes for solid and liquid fuel barbeques and ovens, don‚Äôt do it. On the spot fines of up to $476 and maximums of $15k are possible, it‚Äôs not worth it! If convicted, you can be imprisoned for two years, yep.  Why the rules? Bushfires every year are caused by escaped campfires. That puts the community and environment at risk.  So be safe, follow the rules and read more here: http://bit.ly/CampfireBrochure

Due to the extreme weather conditions and in the interest of Public Safety ‚Äì  Parks Victoria have closed all entry both parking and walking tracks in and around the Ferntree Gully Picnic Ground (including 1000 Steps) at Tremont.  People are still attempting to access this area via foot or parking nearby which is causing concern to both Police and Parks Victoria. Other Areas of note which are closed today include:   - Dandenong Ranges National Park Areas include: One Tree Hill, Doongalla, Valley, Eagles Nest, Sherbrooke and O‚ÄôDonohues picnic grounds, Kalorama Park. Grants Picnic Ground south end is closed but the bird feeding, souvenir shop, restaurant and the rest of the picnic ground will be open. - Dandenong Ranges Botanic Garden (formerly National Rhododendron Gardens) - Dandenong Ranges gardens including: Alfred Nicholas Gardens, Pirianda Garden, George Tindale Garden - Yellowgum Recreation Area (including Blue Lake) at Plenty Gorge Park - RJ Hamer Aboretum - Sassafrass Creek NCR - Silvan Reservoir Park - Norman Reserve, Jumping Creek Reserve and Koornong Reserve at Warrandyte State Park. - William Ricketts Sanctuary - Woodlands Historic Park   Please refer to the parks Victoria Web page for further information.

POLICE SEARCH FOR MISSING BREANNA BOURKE  Police are appealing for public assistance to help locate missing 16 year-old Breanna Bourke.  Breanna was last seen on the 2 January 2018 in the Boolarra area.  Police have concerns for her welfare due to her age.  Breanna is approximately 150cm tall with brown hair and is petite.  Breanna is believed to be in Morwell however she could also be in the other areas of Gippsland.    Police have also released an image of Breanna in the hope someone recognises her  and can provide information regarding her current whereabouts.  If you know where Breanna is please contact the Morwell Police Station on 5131 5000.

Yesterday the 24 day state wide operation, Operation Roadwise came to an end.  Operation Roadwise focused on speed, fatigue, impaired driving, distraction offences and seatbelt compliance.  Throughout the 24 day period police were out and about in an attempt to reinforce positive driving behaviours and lessen the incidence of road trauma.  As a result police in Cardinia detected a total of 507 offences, 470 of those were general traffic offences and 37 involved impaired drivers.  Police conducted a total of 10,576 preliminary breath tests in the Cardinia area with 1 in 387 drivers testing positive for drugs or alcohol in the region.  Although Operation Roadwise has come to a conclusion, police will continue with high levels of road policing enforcement activity.  Police urge all drivers not to let down their guard - continue to exercise patience, take regular breaks of driving long distances and remain focused when driving.  Police will be working hard to continue to drive down trauma in Cardinia during 2018.  #operationroadwise #roadtozero

Summer has started it is a good time for us all to start thinking about the risk of bushfire. The Carrum Downs and Langwarrin areas can be impacted by bushfire and grassfires can occur across our whole service area. Victoria Police address the fire risk across the state with Operation Firesetter and at our local area we run a high visibility prevention and detection response.  How can you help?  We really need you to be our ‚Äòeyes and ears‚Äô within community and call 000 if you see a person/vehicle behaving suspiciously on a high fire danger day.  Or if your suspicion is not urgent you can call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.    You all live in a great area with beautiful flora, fauna and lovely beaches.  Let‚Äôs keep it that way and we can all enjoy the great Australian summer

Assistant Commissioner Rob Hill and Inspector Rob Clarke joined Frankston Mayor Colin Hampton and Bishop of Miletoupolis Jakob Jakovos along with over 1000 people at the Frankston Waterfront, to celebrate the annual Blessing of the Waters on the 6th January 2018.  The highlight of the event is the rush to retrieve the blessed cross, thrown from the pier into the water as Greek tradition says the person who retrieves the cross will be blessed with good fortune for the coming year.  This year‚Äôs winner was Frankie FERRARO from Lysterfield who was then afforded the privilege of dining with the bishop, mayor and dignitaries.

Remain Vigilant This Fire season  Victoria is one of the highest bushfire risk areas in the world. Local police are urging local residents to be mindful of activities during the fire danger period this summer and report any suspicious behaviour to police.  If you believe a person, or a vehicle is behaving in a suspicious manner write the details down as soon as possible. The sooner you write them down the more accurate they are likely to be, and the more helpful the information will be to police.   If you hear or see anything that just doesn't seem right or appears to be suspicious immediately report it to police by calling Triple Zero (000). Alternatively, if a member of the public suspects someone of bushfire arson, Crime Stoppers can be called on 1800 333 000

In the last week there has been a spate of theft from motor vehicles in the Carrum Downs and Skye areas. Tradesmen‚Äôs utility vehicles appeared to be frequently targeted. Windows have been smashed and/or canopy‚Äôs forced open in order to steal power tools from these vehicles.   Police are appealing for the public to be vigilant and to show awareness when it comes to security of property and specifically on this occasion power tools. Police advise the public to upgrade security measures where required with alarms or security cameras, lock your vehicle, remove all valuable items where practicable, identify their property by engraving or marking the item, secure their property in a safer locked location such as garages, sheds etc.    If this happens at your premises please call 000 asap so Police can respond and react in good time.

Should I let my teenagers have a drink of alcohol? A. Parents and carers should be advised that children under 15 years of age are at the greatest risk of harm from drinking and that for this age group, not drinking alcohol is especially important. B. For young people aged 15‚àí17 years, the safest option is to delay the initiation of drinking for as long as possible. Put simply, it is best for young people aged under 18 years to avoid drinking alcohol. It is also important to understand that young adults aged up to 25 years are also still at greater risk of alcohol-related harms. This is due to their lower tolerance of alcohol, greater risk of accidents and injuries, and increased risk of impairments to the still-developing brain. Information from The Family Peace Foundation website.

Police are wanting to know if anyone saw this vehicle on the day and might have witnessed suspicious behaviour at the time.  Between 10.30am and 1pm on the 6th of January 2018 the victim parked his 1995 Chevrolet on the side of Ironbark Rd, Ingliston at the entry of "Falcons Lookout" - 200mtrs past the railway line intersects with Ironbark Rd.  The vehicle was parked at this location while the victim walked to the lookout, a period of 2-1/2hours.  On return the vehicle had been taken by unknown offender/s. The vehicle is green in colour and its registration is  TMSTOY. It was a very hot day last Saturday and most people would recall where they were on the day.  If you Saw Something...Say Something contact Crime Stoppers on 1800333000 or https://www.crimestoppersvic.com.au/report-a-crime/ Please use Ref# 003/18 Ballarat EYEWATCH - TMSTOY Chevrolet

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Dandenong Police Service Area
Post Message: On the 6th of January 2018 police responded to a job in relation to a suspicious vehicle in Kleine Street, Noble Park.  At approximately 1:10am police located a silver Hyundai with a male driver and two female passengers.  A search of the vehicle was conducted and a homemade firearm, a modified firearm and ammunition were located inside the vehicle.  All occupants of the vehicle were arrested and conveyed to the Dandenong Police Station for interview. As a result of the incident a 29 year old male from Doveton was charged and remanded, a 36 year old female from Springvale South was charged and bailed and a 28 year old female was transferred into the custody of Border Security in relation to her immigration status.  Police encourage anyone who notices a person or vehicle acting suspiciously to contact their local police station or 000.  Reporting even the smallest piece of information to police can have an important result.  vp40485

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Dandenong Police Service Area
Post Message: Greater Dandenong Crime Investigation Unit are investigating a fire which occurred on the 2nd of January 2018 at 8:30pm.  Police members were flagged down by members of the public after a mattress and couch were set alight at a unit block on Hemmings Street, Dandenong.  The fire caused a large amount of smoke trapping several residents inside, the evacuation of 4 families and a resident to be transported to hospital.  The CFA attended and extinguished the fire, however, at this stage it is believed the cause of the fire is suspicious.   Police are appealing to the public for any witnesses who may have any information in relation to the incident to contact Senior Constable Matthew Moore at Greater Dandenong Crime Investigation Unit on 9767 7470.  Alternatively you can contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or www.crimestoppers.com.au and quote incident number 180002645  vp40485

DEMERIT POINTS  It‚Äôs a common misunderstanding that everyone starts with 12 demerit points, and that you lose points for committing driving offences but this is incorrect.  All drivers start with 0 demerit points and if you commit a driving offence, you may incur demerit points. The number of demerit points you might receive, depends on the driving offence.  For more information visit VicRoads  VPS Phelps

At 1548 hours on 17/11/2017, two males and one female attended the Australian Geographic store at Bayside Shopping Centre, 28 Beach St, Frankston.   One male removed a display machine before taking a box and leaving the store making no attempt to pay. The box contained a XYZ Da Vinci Pro 1.0 3D printer, valued at $1399.99.   The second male and female exited the store a short time later, leaving the shopping centre via a different route, making a phone call before running to the same exit onto Beach St as the first male offender.   The first male is described as around 180cm tall, Caucasian, approximately 45 years-old, solid build, clean shaven with a dark crew cut, wearing black singlet, black Adidas track pants, black Adidas sneakers, sunglasses on head.  The second male is described as around 190cm tall, Caucasian, approximately 45 years-old, medium build, dark/grey crew cut, clean shaven, wearing blue jeans, blue singlet, thongs, carrying keys on a lanyard.  The female offender is described as around 180cm tall, Caucasian, approximately 35-40 years-old, slim build, tied back ginger/brown hair, wearing black T shirt with 'Russell' logo, black pants, thongs, sunglasses, handbag and tattoos described as a black script on right foot and design on rear of neck.  If you have any information please contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or Senior Constable Ken Matthews at the Frankston Police Station on 9784 5555.

CAN YOU ASSIST POLICE WITH THIS INVESTIGATION  At 8.23pm on 21.12.17 a male drove a black Ford Focus registration number SYL 884 to Geelong Financial Group in Latrobe Terrace. Male then sighted a slab of Corona sitting next to  the door which had been left for staff, male took same and leaving in a vehicle.  Inc # 170426267 relates.  The same vehicle and male are also wanted for a theft in Leopold on the 18.12.17  Inc # 170414842 relates.  Then male pictured above will be able to assist police with this investigation.  If you know the identity of the male pictured or the registered owner of the vehicle you are requested to contact First Constable ARMSTRONG Geelong Youth Tasking Unit 5225 3100 or Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 and ref the numbers above.

Australia Day celebrations open to the local community, will be held at the Whittlesea Municipal office grounds in Ferres Blvd, South Morang on Friday the 26th January 2018, commencing at 5.00 PM.   There will be live entertainment, numerous fun activities and information tents for both children and adults.   The consumption of BYO alcohol is permitted within the grounds, however the event will see a strong visible presence of Police and private security to ensure the safety and enjoyment of all those attending.   Please consider your consumption of alcohol especially if you intend to drive as Police will be conducting alcohol and drug testing on surrounding roads.   For those catching public transport  there will be extra PSO‚Äôs staffing the South Morang Railway Station.

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Dandenong Police Service Area
Post Message: Did you get caught up in the traffic on the Monash Freeway just before midday today?  A motorist was travelling inbound on the Monash, just after the Eastlink on-ramp when he smelt what he thought was newly laid asphalt from the roadworks...nek minit...check engine symbol lights up and the car is engulfed in flames.  The driver was able to pull the vehicle off the road just in time.  The female passenger sustained minor burns to her leg and was transported to Dandenong Hospital, however, thanks to the drivers quick thinking serious injuries were avoided. The CFA attended and dealt with the flames with a number of police units attending including 3 of our marked motorcyles.  vp40485

POLICE APPEAL FOR WITNESS  On the 30th of December 2017, a rider was riding her "Avanti" road bike in an Easterly direction on Glengarry West Rod, near Burnet Park Road.  The rider observed a 4wd and a sedan travelling in the opposite direction. The sedan pulled into the left hand lane to overtake the 4wd.  The sedan appeared to be travelling at speed and did not see the rider.  To avoid a collision with the sedan, the rider took evasive action and steered her bike into the grassy embankment where she fell and hurt her arm.  Nil registration plates were obtained and no further description of the vehicles involved.  Police are appealling for anyone who witnessed this incident or has any information to contact the Churchill Police Station on (03) 51221790 or contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or submit a confidential report at www.crimestoppersvic.com.au

Update on the Moe assault.  Latrobe Crime Investigation Unit detectives with the assistance of the members at Moe Police Station have charged three girls following an alleged assault in Moe early Monday morning.   Two 15-year-old Moe girls were charged with assault and robbery and were remanded in custody to appear at a children‚Äôs court at a later date. A 12-year-old Moe girl was also charged with assault and robbery and bailed to appear at a children‚Äôs court at a later date.   The charges relate to an alleged assault at a park on Vale Street in Moe about 3am. A 17-year-old Moe girl sustained facial injuries during the assault. She was taken to hospital and released later that day.   Police have also undertaken reassurance patrols following the incident.

Did you know that the temperature inside a vehicle can be as much as 30-40 degrees hotter than the outside temperature? Earlier today Knox Police received a report of a person sighted with a visible firearm sticking out of their football shorts on a bus that was arriving at Westfield Knox City. Police would like to remind the public that this sort of behavior is treated very seriously - particularly at a large shopping centre and in the heightened security environment that we now live in.  Any witnesses or other information can be directed to Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000. - Sergeant 32413 -

B.B.Q Safely this summer  At this time of year our fire services experience an increase in the number of fires relating to barbecues.   The most common causes of the fires include leaking or loosely fitted gas hoses, poorly maintained B.B.Q's and B.B.Q's being left unattended for a period of time. Follow the tips below to keep your B.B.Q working efficiently and safely:  - Check the gas cylinder is not damaged before you turn it on and ensure it has been tested within the last 10 years - Check gas hoses for damage and leaks - Check connections are tight and not leaking before operation - Clean fat and grease from the barbecue before use - Change your gas cyclinders at a reputable supplier  For further information check the following websites:  www.mfb.vic.gov.au www.cfa.vic.gov.au

Facebook Page: Eyewatch - Greater Dandenong Police Service Area
Post Message: Police are encouraging licenced venues in Greater Dandenong to sign up to the recently re-established Greater Dandenong Liquor Accord which is aimed at improving public safety in and around licensed premises.   The accord is one avenue police use to help enforce liquor laws and reduce violence and other unacceptable behaviour.   Dandenong police Sergeant Pat Green has worked closely with licensees to drive an inclusive and robust Liquor Accord which is geared towards education and networking.    Sgt Green said while compliance was a responsibility of licensees, an effective relationship with police would reduce risk of offences occurring in the first place.      Greater Dandenong licensing Inspector Mark Langhorn said some of the benefits of being a Liquor Accord member include an agreement to a standard of responsible management for the licensed premises, community recognition for commitment and a clearly articulated link between the accord and overall community safety strategies.     ‚ÄúIt is vital to the success of a Liquor Accord that we have a good representative group to discuss issues that impact the liquor industry,‚Äù he said.    ‚ÄúI commend licensees to the Greater Dandenong Liquor Accord which will provide the platform to network with other key stakeholders.‚Äù    The next Liquor Accord meeting is set for 3pm on Tuesday, 6 March, 2018.     Expressions of interest to become a member of the Greater Dandenong Liquor Accord can be emailed to Sgt Green at greater-dandenong-li@police.vic.gov.au
